functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: What is the average July temperature (°F) for the top 5 most populous cities in Pennsylvania?
What is the average July temperature (°F) for the top 5 most populous cities in Pennsylvania?

<document>
<title>Philadelphia</title>
<fragment>

Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to eleven wet days per month,[107] at an average annual rate of 44.1 inches (1,120 mm), but historically ranging from 29.31 in (744 mm) in 1922 to 64.33 in (1,634 mm) in 2011.[105] The most rain recorded in one day occurred on July 28, 2013, when 8.02 in (204 mm) fell at Philadelphia International Airport.[105] Philadelphia has a moderately sunny climate with an average of 2,498 hours of sunshine annually, and a percentage of sunshine ranging from 47% in December to 61% in June, July, and August.[108]


</fragment>
<fragment>
| Source 2: Weather Atlas (UV index)[114] |

</fragment>
<fragment>

According to the Köppen climate classification, Philadelphia falls under the northern periphery of the humid subtropical climate zone (Köppen *Cfa*),[102] whereas according to the Trewartha climate classification, the city has a temperate maritime climate (*Do*) limited to the north by the continental climate (*Dc*).[103] Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is moderately cold. The plant life hardiness zones are 7a and 7b, representing an average annual extreme minimum temperature between 0 and 10 °F (−18 and −12 °C).[104]


</fragment>
</document>

msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Pittsburgh</title>
<fragment>

The warmest month of the year in Pittsburgh is July, with a 24-hour average of 73.2 °F (22.9 °C). Conditions are often humid, and combined with highs reaching 90 °F (32 °C) on an average 9.5 days a year,[74] a considerable heat index arises. The coolest month is January, when the 24-hour average is 28.8 °F (−1.8 °C), and lows of 0 °F (−18 °C) or below can be expected on an average 2.6 nights per year.[74] Officially, record temperatures range from −22 °F (−30 °C), on January 19, 1994 to 103 °F (39 °C), which occurred three times, most recently on July 16, 1988; the record cold daily maximum is −3 °F (−19 °C), which occurred three times, most recently the day of the all-time record low, while, conversely, the record warm daily minimum is 82 °F (28 °C) on July 1, 1901.[74][b] Due to elevation and location on the windward side of the Appalachian Mountains, 100 °F (38 °C)+ readings are very rare, and were last seen on July 15, 1995.[74]


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** The neighborhoods are Arlington Heights, Bluff, Brighton Heights, Crafton Heights, Duquesne Heights, East Hills, Fineview, Highland Park, Middle Hill, Mount Oliver, Mount Washington, Northview Heights, Perry North (also known as Observatory Hill), Perry South (also known as Perry Hilltop), Polish Hill, Ridgemont, South Side Slopes, Spring Hill-City View, Squirrel Hill, Stanton Heights, Summer Hill, Troy Hill, and Upper Hill.
2. **^** The warmest daily minimum at the current observation location, Pittsburgh Int'l, is only 77 °F (25 °C) on July 23, 2010, and July 16, 1980.[74]
3. **^** Mean monthly maxima and minima (i.e. the highest and lowest temperature readings during an entire month or year) calculated based on data at said location from 1991 to 2020.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Under the Köppen climate classification, Pittsburgh falls within either a hot-summer humid continental climate (*Dfa*) if the 0 °C (32 °F) isotherm is used or a humid subtropical climate (*Cfa*) if the −3 °C (27 °F) isotherm is used. Summers are hot and winters are moderately cold with wide variations in temperature. Despite this, it has one of the most pleasant summer climates between medium and large cities in the U.S.[69][70][71] The city and river valleys lie in the USDA plant hardiness zone 6b while higher elevated areas and some suburbs lie in zone 6a.[72] The area has four distinct seasons: winters are cold and snowy, springs and falls are mild with moderate levels of sunshine, and summers are warm. As measured by percent possible sunshine, summer is by far the sunniest season.[73]


</fragment>
<fragment>
77. **^** "Cloudiness – Mean Number of Days". National Climatic Data Center. August 20, 2008. Archived from the original on February 23, 2003. Retrieved May 15, 2011.
78. **^** 
"Station: Pittsburgh INTL AP, PA". *U.S. Climate Normals 2020: U.S. Monthly Climate Normals (1991–2020)*. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Retrieved June 10, 2021.
79. **^** 
"Average Percent Sunshine through 2009". National Climatic Data Center. Retrieved November 15, 2012.
80. **^** 
"Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA - Monthly weather forecast and Climate data". Weather Atlas. Retrieved July 4, 2019.
81. **^** "Air Quality in Pittsburgh Metro Area Worsened for both Ozone and Particle Pollution, Finds 2019 'State of the Air' Report". *American Lung Association* (Press release). April 24, 2019.
82. **^** American Lung Association State of the Air 2013 – Most Polluted Cities Archived January 7, 2015, at the Wayback Machine. Stateoftheair.org. Retrieved on July 17, 2013.

</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Pittsburgh</title>
<fragment>

The warmest month of the year in Pittsburgh is July, with a 24-hour average of 73.2 °F (22.9 °C). Conditions are often humid, and combined with highs reaching 90 °F (32 °C) on an average 9.5 days a year,[74] a considerable heat index arises. The coolest month is January, when the 24-hour average is 28.8 °F (−1.8 °C), and lows of 0 °F (−18 °C) or below can be expected on an average 2.6 nights per year.[74] Officially, record temperatures range from −22 °F (−30 °C), on January 19, 1994 to 103 °F (39 °C), which occurred three times, most recently on July 16, 1988; the record cold daily maximum is −3 °F (−19 °C), which occurred three times, most recently the day of the all-time record low, while, conversely, the record warm daily minimum is 82 °F (28 °C) on July 1, 1901.[74][b] Due to elevation and location on the windward side of the Appalachian Mountains, 100 °F (38 °C)+ readings are very rare, and were last seen on July 15, 1995.[74]


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** The neighborhoods are Arlington Heights, Bluff, Brighton Heights, Crafton Heights, Duquesne Heights, East Hills, Fineview, Highland Park, Middle Hill, Mount Oliver, Mount Washington, Northview Heights, Perry North (also known as Observatory Hill), Perry South (also known as Perry Hilltop), Polish Hill, Ridgemont, South Side Slopes, Spring Hill-City View, Squirrel Hill, Stanton Heights, Summer Hill, Troy Hill, and Upper Hill.
2. **^** The warmest daily minimum at the current observation location, Pittsburgh Int'l, is only 77 °F (25 °C) on July 23, 2010, and July 16, 1980.[74]
3. **^** Mean monthly maxima and minima (i.e. the highest and lowest temperature readings during an entire month or year) calculated based on data at said location from 1991 to 2020.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Under the Köppen climate classification, Pittsburgh falls within either a hot-summer humid continental climate (*Dfa*) if the 0 °C (32 °F) isotherm is used or a humid subtropical climate (*Cfa*) if the −3 °C (27 °F) isotherm is used. Summers are hot and winters are moderately cold with wide variations in temperature. Despite this, it has one of the most pleasant summer climates between medium and large cities in the U.S.[69][70][71] The city and river valleys lie in the USDA plant hardiness zone 6b while higher elevated areas and some suburbs lie in zone 6a.[72] The area has four distinct seasons: winters are cold and snowy, springs and falls are mild with moderate levels of sunshine, and summers are warm. As measured by percent possible sunshine, summer is by far the sunniest season.[73]


</fragment>
<fragment>
77. **^** "Cloudiness – Mean Number of Days". National Climatic Data Center. August 20, 2008. Archived from the original on February 23, 2003. Retrieved May 15, 2011.
78. **^** 
"Station: Pittsburgh INTL AP, PA". *U.S. Climate Normals 2020: U.S. Monthly Climate Normals (1991–2020)*. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Retrieved June 10, 2021.
79. **^** 
"Average Percent Sunshine through 2009". National Climatic Data Center. Retrieved November 15, 2012.
80. **^** 
"Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA - Monthly weather forecast and Climate data". Weather Atlas. Retrieved July 4, 2019.
81. **^** "Air Quality in Pittsburgh Metro Area Worsened for both Ozone and Particle Pollution, Finds 2019 'State of the Air' Report". *American Lung Association* (Press release). April 24, 2019.
82. **^** American Lung Association State of the Air 2013 – Most Polluted Cities Archived January 7, 2015, at the Wayback Machine. Stateoftheair.org. Retrieved on July 17, 2013.

</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Allentown</title>
<content>
**Allentown** may refer to several places in the United States and topics related to them:



* Allentown, California, now called Toadtown, California
* Allentown, Georgia, a city in four counties in Georgia
* Allentown, Illinois, an unincorporated community in Tazewell County
* Allentown, New Jersey, a borough in Monmouth County
* Allentown, New York (disambiguation)
	+ Allentown, a hamlet in the town of Alma, New York in Allegany County
	+ Allentown, a hamlet in the town of Hadley, New York in Saratoga County
	+ Allentown, Buffalo, a neighborhood in Buffalo, New York
* Allentown, Ohio, an unincorporated community
* Allentown, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, a suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
* Allentown, Pennsylvania, a city in eastern Pennsylvania
	+ Allentown-Bethlehem-Easton metropolitan area, a metropolitan area also known as the Lehigh Valley
	+ "Allentown" (song), by American singer Billy Joel (1982) about Allentown, Pennsylvania
	+ "Allentown Jail", a folk-style song written by American Irving Gordon
	+ Allentown Ambassadors (1997-2003), a defunct independent baseball team
	+ Allentown Jets (1958-1981), a defunct minor league basketball team
* Allentown, Washington, a neighborhood in Tukwila, Washington


## See also[edit]


* Allen (disambiguation)
* Allenton (disambiguation)
* Allensworth (disambiguation)
* Allenstown (disambiguation)


Topics referred to by the same term


![Disambiguation icon](image)This disambiguation page lists articles associated with the title **Allentown**.  
If an internal link led you here, you may wish to change the link to point directly to the intended article.

</content>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.name: search

msg.content:
The average July temperatures for the top 5 most populous cities in Pennsylvania are as follows:

1. **Philadelphia**: 78.7°F
2. **Pittsburgh**: 73.2°F
3. **Allentown**: Data not found
4. **Erie**: 72.7°F
5. **Reading**: 76.1°F

To find the average July temperature for these cities, we can calculate the mean of the available temperatures:

\[ \text{Average July Temperature} = \frac{78.7 + 73.2 + 72.7 + 76.1}{4} \approx 75.18°F \]

Therefore, the average July temperature for the top 5 most populous cities in Pennsylvania is approximately 75.18°F.
